Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the increase in Medicare insurance premiums, stating that it will be "$120.20 per month in 2013 and $247.00 per month in 2014," which is more than double in one year.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the actual projected Medicare premiums provided in the 2012 report from the board of trustees, which estimates the standard monthly premium to be about $109.10 a month in 2013 and about $3 more in 2014.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support or evidence to back up the assertion that the increase in premiums was purposely delayed for political reasons.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the increase in premiums is due to the 2012 Re-Election Campaigns or Obamacare, without providing any evidence or logical reasoning to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim suggests that the increase in premiums is due to political reasons or Obamacare, but the expert's verdict provides an alternative explanation that higher-income seniors are charged more, a provision that was in place before Obamacare was passed.
Falters at times: The claim falters by providing incorrect information about the current and projected Medicare premiums, as well as attributing the false claim to Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Alabama, which the company denies.
Understate: There is no evidence of understating bias in this claim.
